text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Olof Forssberg, Swedish head of the commission investigating the 1994 Estonia ferry disaster, was forced to resign by Communications Minister Ines Uusmann after he admitted lying to a journalist.
- One reactor at the Barseback nuclear power stattion in southwest Sweden wil close by July 1998 no matter what the results are of negotiations between power station owner Sydkraft and the state.

- The share price in Swedish insurance company Skandia has risen sharply in the past two days as the market evaluates the potential of the group's U.S. unit linked division, AFS, which continues to expand year after year.
- A flexible Swedish labour market is necessary to ensure Sweden does not develop growth without creating new jobs, Riksbank Governor Urban Backstrom says.

- A few hundred Ericsson employees will be offered the option of moving to Scotland to work for SCI Systems which will manufacture printed boards for Ericsson. The Swedish company has decided to close its Norrkoping plant and outsource the work but SCI Systems.

- The jobless rate among workers in Sweden's construction industry is over 30 percent. Many are hoping Prime Minister Goran Persson will announce measures to stimulate the industry when he speaks at a seminar on Wednesday.

- Since Swedish investment company Incentive made a 12 billion crown bid for U.S. health service company Vivra, the share soared. Incentive executives' stock options worth has increased by 60 million crowns.

- Swedish state-owned telecoms company Telia was the winner of the race for new mobile telephone subscribers last year. Telia Mobile now has 865,000 subscribers for its GSM system, or 70 percent of the market.
- State-owned postal systems of Sweden and Finland have signed a letter of intent of increase cooperation which will include joint handling of package shipments and logistics.
